hints: A new type of computing that uses the principles of quantum mechanics.
Uses qubits instead of traditional bits.
Could solve problems that are impossible for classical computers.
A subfield of AI that enables systems to learn from data.
Used for tasks like pattern recognition and prediction.
An algorithm 'learns' and improves over time without being explicitly programmed.
Overlays digital information onto the real world.
Popular applications include Pok√©mon Go and Snapchat filters.
Often used with smartphones or smart glasses.
Uses unique biological characteristics to verify identity.
Examples include fingerprint scanners and facial recognition.
A more advanced form of authentication than passwords.
A decentralized digital ledger technology.
It is the underlying technology behind most cryptocurrencies.
Data is stored in 'blocks' that are linked together and are immutable.
A subset of machine learning using multi-layered neural networks.
Powers advanced applications like image recognition and natural language processing.
Requires a very large amount of data and computational power.
The network of physical devices embedded with sensors and software.
Enables everyday objects to connect and exchange data.
Think of smart home devices like thermostats and fridges.
The fifth generation of cellular network technology.
Offers faster speeds and lower latency than its predecessor.
Essential for future developments like autonomous vehicles.
Uses software bots to automate repetitive business tasks.
Commonly abbreviated as RPA.
Mimics human actions to perform tasks like data entry.
A type of AI that can create new, original content.
Includes models like DALL-E and ChatGPT.
Can generate text, images, music, and more.
A gene-editing tool that can modify DNA.
Commonly referred to as 'molecular scissors'.
Has potential applications in medicine and agriculture.
Processing data closer to its source, rather than a centralized cloud.
Reduces latency and bandwidth usage.
Crucial for real-time applications and IoT devices.
A simulated 3D environment that can be explored.
Requires a headset to fully immerse the user.
Has applications in gaming, training, and therapy.
The manipulation of matter on an atomic, molecular, and supramolecular scale.
Deals with objects with at least one dimension less than 100 nanometers.
Used in materials science, electronics, and medicine.
Allows a direct communication pathway between the brain and an external device.
Often abbreviated as BCI.
Could help people with paralysis control devices with their thoughts.
A unique digital asset stored on a blockchain.
Often represents ownership of digital art or collectibles.
Commonly abbreviated as NFT.
A hypothetical type of AI that can understand and learn any intellectual task.
Often abbreviated as AGI.
The 'holy grail' of AI research.
Recreates the sense of touch by applying forces, vibrations, or motions.
Used in gaming controllers and VR gloves.
Provides tactile feedback to the user.
A modern security approach that moves away from traditional perimeters.
Distributes security controls across a network.
The model assumes that threats can originate from inside or outside the network.
Uses light waves to transmit data wirelessly.
An alternative to Wi-Fi, offering faster speeds.
The name is a portmanteau of Light Fidelity.
Self-executing contracts with the terms of the agreement directly written into code.
They run on a blockchain.
Automates the execution of an agreement.
A network of 3D virtual worlds focused on social connection.
Often referred to as the next generation of the internet.
Combines aspects of virtual and augmented reality.
A robot with a body shape built to resemble the human body.
Often designed to perform human tasks in human environments.
Notable examples include Atlas by Boston Dynamics and Optimus by Tesla.
Tiny semiconductor nanocrystals.
Emit light when exposed to UV light.
Used in modern QLED TVs for improved color display.
A device that converts chemical energy from hydrogen into electricity.
Produces only water and heat as byproducts.
Considered a clean energy source for vehicles.
Delivering healthcare services remotely using technology.
Includes virtual doctor visits and remote monitoring.
Increased in popularity due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
A computing system inspired by the human brain.
Made up of interconnected nodes or 'neurons'.
Forms the foundation of deep learning algorithms.
The third generation of the internet.
It aims to be decentralized and based on blockchain technology.
Focuses on user ownership and control of data.
Refers to the use of unmanned aerial vehicles.
Used for surveillance, delivery, and photography.
Controlled remotely by an operator.
Self-driving cars and other transport that can operate without a human driver.
Uses sensors, cameras, and AI to navigate.
Often referred to as AVs.
Corrects genetic defects to treat disease.
Introduces new genes into a patient's cells.
Used to treat inherited disorders like cystic fibrosis.
Electronic devices worn on the body.
Examples include smartwatches and fitness trackers.
Collects data about the user's health and activity.
A two-dimensional material composed of a single layer of carbon atoms.
Known for being incredibly strong and a great conductor of electricity.
A potential 'wonder material' for electronics.
Storing and accessing data and programs over the internet.
Instead of a computer's hard drive.
Examples include services like AWS, Google Cloud, and Azure.
A digital or virtual currency secured by cryptography.
Operates on a decentralized public ledger.
Bitcoin is the most well-known example.
A process of making a three-dimensional solid object from a digital file.
Also known as additive manufacturing.
Used to create prototypes and complex parts layer by layer.
The blending of physical and digital worlds.
It is a hybrid of augmented and virtual reality.
Allows for real-time interaction between real and virtual objects.
A field of AI that trains computers to interpret and understand the visual world.
Used in self-driving cars to 'see' the road.
Enables facial recognition and object detection.
Microscopic robots that can operate at the nanoscale.
Potential applications in medicine for targeted drug delivery.
Can perform specific tasks at a molecular level.
Urban areas that use technology to improve efficiency and quality of life.
Uses sensors and data to manage traffic, waste, and energy.
Examples include Singapore and Seoul.
A proposed high-speed transportation system.
Uses pods traveling through low-pressure tubes.
Elon Musk popularized this concept.
A cloud execution model where the provider dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources.
Users don't have to worry about managing servers.
Often used for short, event-driven functions.
A cybersecurity model that assumes no user or device can be trusted.
Requires verification from everyone, inside and outside the network.
The core principle is 'never trust, always verify'.
The application of biological methods and systems found in nature to engineering.
Examples include prosthetic limbs that can be controlled by the brain.
Blends biology and electronics.
Any technology that interacts with the nervous system or brain.
Includes brain-computer interfaces and neuroprosthetics.
A blend of neuroscience and engineering.
Uses the principles of quantum mechanics to secure communication.
It can detect any attempts to eavesdrop on a conversation.
Promises unhackable communication in the future.
The medical application of nanotechnology.
Uses nanomaterials for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of diseases.
Can be used for targeted drug delivery.
Materials engineered to have properties not found in naturally occurring substances.
Their properties come from their structure, not their composition.
Potential applications include invisibility cloaks.
A form of energy generated by fusing light atomic nuclei.
It is the same process that powers the sun and stars.
Promises a clean and virtually limitless energy source.
Technology whose use is intended to mitigate human impact on the environment.
Examples include solar panels and wind turbines.
Also known as 'clean tech'.
Uses quantum mechanics to make highly precise measurements.
Can be used to detect changes in magnetic fields or gravity.
Could lead to more accurate medical imaging.
An American aerospace manufacturer and space transportation company.
Founded by Elon Musk.
Known for its reusable rockets like the Falcon 9.
The process of quickly jotting down all thoughts on a topic.
A productivity technique often used in brainstorming sessions.
Helps to clear one's mind and organize ideas.
A technology that projects a 3D image that can be seen without special glasses.
Creates a virtual object in real space.
Think of the sci-fi movies like Star Wars.
A field that redesigns biological components and systems.
Uses engineering principles to create new biological functions.
Has applications in medicine and energy production.
A neurotechnology company founded by Elon Musk.
Its goal is to develop implantable brain-computer interfaces.
Aims to help people with neurological disorders.
A low-level language for web browsers.
Enables high-performance applications on the web.
Often abbreviated as WASM.
A foundational technology for connecting and managing IoT devices.
Provides tools for data collection and analytics.
Examples include Amazon IoT and Google Cloud IoT.
Uses 3D printing techniques to create tissue and organs.
Uses 'bio ink' made of living cells.
Aims to solve the organ donor shortage.
A concept in physics that combines space and time into a single continuum.
The fabric of the universe, according to Einstein's theory of relativity.
Gravity is described as a curvature in this fabric.
Integrations of computation, networking, and physical processes.
Examples include smart grids and autonomous vehicles.
Often abbreviated as CPS.
A type of LED that uses quantum dots to produce pure monochromatic light.
Used in QLED TVs.
Results in a wider and more vibrant color gamut.
A hypothetical system of tiny wireless sensors.
Could be scattered over a large area to collect data.
Each 'grain' contains a sensor, computer, and communication device.
A financial system built on public blockchains.
Removes the need for central intermediaries like banks.
Commonly abbreviated as DeFi.
Vehicles that use hydrogen fuel cells to generate electricity.
Also known as FCEVs.
Their only emission is water vapor.
A form of artificial intelligence that has consciousness and self-awareness.
A highly debated and theoretical future of AI.
Possesses the ability to feel and perceive.
A type of evolutionary algorithm used to solve optimization problems.
Inspired by the process of natural selection.
It 'evolves' solutions over generations.
A field of AI that enables computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language.
Powers applications like chatbots and translation services.
Commonly abbreviated as NLP.
An electricity network that uses digital communication technology.
Optimizes power distribution and increases efficiency.
Uses two-way communication between the utility and the consumer.
A medical device inserted into the brain to treat neurological conditions.
Also known as a neural implant.
Can restore lost functions or control external devices.
Devices that analyze real-world objects to collect data on their shape and color.
Creates a digital 3D model of the object.
Used in reverse engineering and quality control.
A synthetic porous ultralight material derived from a gel.
It is a solid with extremely low density.
Known as 'frozen smoke'.
A type of battery that uses liquid metals for its electrodes.
Designed for large-scale energy storage.
Can store a large amount of energy at a low cost.
A method of secure communication using quantum mechanics.
Ensures the privacy of the keys used to encrypt information.
It is a form of quantum cryptography.
A type of AI that simulates human thought processes.
Aims to solve complex problems by understanding natural language.
IBM's Watson is a well-known example.
The process of converting data into economic value.
Companies can sell data insights or use them to improve products.
A major driver of the digital economy.
The use of computer network attacks by a nation-state.
Aims to disrupt the activities of another nation-state.
Can target critical infrastructure like power grids.
A type of battery that uses graphene to improve performance.
Offers faster charging times and a longer lifespan.
Still largely in the research and development phase.
Vessels that can navigate and operate without a human crew.
Uses sensors and AI for navigation and collision avoidance.
Being developed for cargo and shipping industries.
Playing video games streamed from a remote server.
Eliminates the need for a powerful local gaming console or PC.
Examples include Xbox Cloud Gaming and GeForce Now.
The use of biological molecules like DNA to perform computations.
A highly experimental form of computing.
Aims to create computers that are smaller and more efficient.
A network that transmits data using quantum mechanics.
Would allow for ultra-secure communication.
Could be used for quantum cryptography on a large scale.
A battery technology that uses a solid electrolyte instead of a liquid one.
Safer and more energy-dense than current lithium-ion batteries.
A key focus for the future of electric vehicles.
Robots with the ability to perceive and respond to feelings.
A concept from science fiction that is being explored in AI.
Would be able to have subjective experiences.
DNA that is artificially created in a lab.
Used in synthetic biology to create new life forms.
Can be used to store data in a highly compact form.
The combination of quantum computing and machine learning.
Aims to use quantum computers to process data faster and more efficiently.
Still in its early stages of research.
The deployment of AI algorithms on local devices rather than in the cloud.
Reduces latency and improves privacy.
Examples include smart speakers and facial recognition on a smartphone.
A network that stores data across many different computers.
No single point of failure.
An alternative to centralized cloud storage services.
Materials that have one or more properties that can be significantly changed in a controlled fashion.
Can respond to external stimuli like temperature or light.
Examples include shape-memory alloys.
The business of flying people into space for recreational purposes.
Companies like Virgin Galactic and Blue Origin are major players.
Makes space travel accessible to private individuals.
A virtual replica of a physical object, process, or system.
Allows for simulation and analysis without affecting the real world.
Used in manufacturing and urban planning.
A device that uses quantum mechanics to produce truly random numbers.
Essential for high-security cryptography.
Cannot be predicted or replicated.
Devices that can substitute a motor or sensory function that has been damaged.
Examples include cochlear implants for hearing and retinal implants for sight.
A form of neurotechnology.
The process of creating data element mappings between two distinct data models.
Used to integrate different data systems.
Essential for data warehousing and migration.
Artificial intelligence integrated into a wearable device.
Examples include smartwatches with built-in voice assistants.
Provides real-time, context-aware information.

Can be used to detect changes in magnetic fields or gravity.
Could lead to more accurate medical imaging.

Provides real-time, context-aware information.

Used in business to predict customer behavior or market trends.
Helps organizations make better decisions.
Plastics derived from renewable biomass sources.
More environmentally friendly than traditional fossil fuel-based plastics.
Can be biodegradable.
A software application or physical device for managing cryptocurrency.
Stores the public and private keys needed to send and receive digital assets.
Essential for interacting with blockchain.
Man-made devices or tissues that mimic the function of a biological organ.
Can be used to replace or support a damaged organ.
A significant development in medical technology.
A satellite designed to transmit entangled photons for secure communication.
Essential for a future global quantum internet.
A Chinese satellite named Micius was the first of its kind.
A field focused on robots that interact and communicate with humans.
Can be used as companions or assistants.
Examples include Pepper and Sophia.
Combines artificial intelligence with geographic data.
Used to analyze satellite imagery and location-based data.
Helps with urban planning and environmental monitoring.

Helps identify patterns and anomalies in network traffic.

Aims to use quantum computers to process data faster and more efficiently.
Still in its early stages of research.
The deployment of AI algorithms on local devices rather than in the cloud.
Reduces latency and improves privacy.
Examples include smart speakers and facial recognition on a smartphone.
A network that stores data across many different computers.
No single point of failure.
An alternative to centralized cloud storage services.
Materials that have one or more properties that can be significantly changed in a controlled fashion.
Can respond to external stimuli like temperature or light.
Examples include shape-memory alloys.
The business of flying people into space for recreational purposes.
Companies like Virgin Galactic and Blue Origin are major players.
Makes space travel accessible to private individuals.
A virtual replica of a physical object, process, or system.
Allows for simulation and analysis without affecting the real world.
Used in manufacturing and urban planning.
A device that uses quantum mechanics to produce truly random numbers.
Essential for high-security cryptography.
Cannot be predicted or replicated.
Devices that can substitute a motor or sensory function that has been damaged.
Examples include cochlear implants for hearing and retinal implants for sight.
A form of neurotechnology.
The process of creating data element mappings between two distinct data models.
Used to integrate different data systems.
Essential for data warehousing and migration.
Artificial intelligence integrated into a wearable device.
Examples include smartwatches with built-in voice assistants.
Provides real-time, context-aware information.
Uses data, algorithms, and machine learning to forecast future outcomes.
Used in business to predict customer behavior or market trends.
Helps organizations make better decisions.
Plastics derived from renewable biomass sources.
More environmentally friendly than traditional fossil fuel-based plastics.
Can be biodegradable.
A software application or physical device for managing cryptocurrency.
Stores the public and private keys needed to send and receive digital assets.
Essential for interacting with blockchain.
Man-made devices or tissues that mimic the function of a biological organ.
Can be used to replace or support a damaged organ.
A significant development in medical technology.
A satellite designed to transmit entangled photons for secure communication.
Essential for a future global quantum internet.
A Chinese satellite named Micius was the first of its kind.
A field focused on robots that interact and communicate with humans.
Can be used as companions or assistants.
Examples include Pepper and Sophia.
Combines artificial intelligence with geographic data.
Used to analyze satellite imagery and location-based data.
Helps with urban planning and environmental monitoring.
The use of big data analytics to detect and prevent cyberattacks.
Helps identify patterns and anomalies in network traffic.

Electronic devices constructed on flexible plastic substrates.
Can be bent, folded, or stretched without breaking.
Used in wearable devices and foldable smartphones.
A data storage device that uses integrated circuit assemblies.
Faster and more durable than traditional hard disk drives.
Commonly abbreviated as SSD.
Using a quantum system to model another quantum system.
Helps scientists understand complex physical phenomena.
Can be used to design new materials and drugs.
A class of machine learning frameworks.
Consists of a 'generator' and a 'discriminator' network.

A proposed high-speed transportation system.

A cloud execution model where the provider dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources.
Users don't have to worry about managing servers.
Often used for short, event-driven functions.
A cybersecurity model that assumes no user or device can be trusted.
Requires verification from everyone, inside and outside the network.
The core principle is 'never trust, always verify'.
The application of biological methods and systems found in nature to engineering.

Any technology that interacts with the nervous system or brain.

The process of quickly jotting down all thoughts on a topic.

A concept in physics that combines space and time into a single continuum.
